Fortenbaugh's "Aristotle on Emotion" (1975), Dorothea Frede's "The Endoxon Mystique" (2012), Cynthia Freeland's edited "Feminist Interpretations of Aristotle", and Hans-Georg Gadamer's "The Idea of the Good in Platonic-Aristotelian Philosophy" (1986).

payload.text: The last set of questions we will examine centers on the pursuit of happiness, both individual and collective. Most of the popular literature on happiness discusses how to make oneself happier, with little attention given to whether this is an appropriate goal, or how various means of pursuing happiness measure up from an ethical standpoint. More broadly, how if at all should one pursue happiness as part of a good life? We saw earlier that most philosophers regard happiness as secondary to morality in a good life. The individual pursuit of happiness may be subject to nonmoral norms as well, prudence being the most obvious among them. Prudential norms need not be as plain as "don't shoot yourself in the foot." On Sumner's authentic happiness view of well-being, for instance, we stand to gain little by pursuing happiness in inauthentic ways, for instance through self-deception or powerful drugs like Huxley's soma, which guarantees happiness come what may (Huxley 1932 [2005]). The view raises interesting questions about the benefits of less extreme pharmaceuticals, such as the therapeutic use of antidepressants; such medications can make life more pleasant, but many people worry whether they pose a threat to authenticity, perhaps undercutting their benefits. It is possible that such drugs involve prudential tradeoffs, promoting well-being in some ways while undermining it in others; whether the tradeoffs are worth it will depend on how, in a given case, the balance is struck. Another possibility is that such drugs sometimes promote authenticity, if for instance a depressive disorder prevents a person from being "himself." Looking to more broadly ethical, but not yet moral, norms, it may be possible to act badly without acting either immorally or imprudently. While Aristotle himself regarded acting badly as inherently imprudent, his catalogue of virtues is instructive, as many of them (wit, friendliness, etc.) are not what we normally regard as moral virtues. Some morally permissible methods of pursuing happiness may nonetheless be inappropriate because they conflict with such "ethical" virtues. They might, for instance, be undignified or imbecilic. Outwardly virtuous conduct undertaken in the name of personal happiness might, if wrongly motivated, be incompatible with genuine virtue. One might, for instance, engage in philanthropy solely to make oneself happier, and indeed work hard at fine-tuning one's assistance to maximize the hedonic payoff.
payload.summary:
The text delves into the pursuit of happiness on both personal and collective levels, primarily focusing on individual happiness. Most literature emphasizes methods to enhance personal happiness without critically evaluating its ethical implications or appropriateness as a life goal. Philosophers generally view happiness as secondary to morality in a good life. Individual pursuit of happiness can be subject to nonmoral norms, such as prudence, which extends beyond simple rules like "don't harm yourself." Sumner's authentic happiness perspective suggests that seeking happiness through inauthentic means, like self-deception or drugs (e.g., Huxley's soma), offers little benefit. This raises questions about the use of less extreme pharmaceuticals, such as antidepressants, which can increase life pleasantness but may compromise authenticity and thus their benefits. These drugs might involve prudential tradeoffs, enhancing well-being in some aspects while diminishing it in others; the value of these tradeoffs depends on how the balance is struck in each case. Some argue that such drugs can promote authenticity by addressing conditions like depression that hinder a person's true self.

Beyond prudence, ethical norms (non-moral but not immoral) may allow for actions that are neither morally wrong nor imprudent yet still inappropriate due to lack of dignity or wisdom. Aristotle's virtues list, though mostly non-moral, illustrates this; some virtues (like wit and friendliness) aren't considered moral virtues. Morally permissible happiness pursuits might conflict with these "ethical" virtues, making them undignified or foolish. Acting virtuously for personal happiness, if motivated incorrectly, could be incompatible with genuine virtue. For example, one might engage in philanthropy solely to boost their own happiness and meticulously plan it to maximize hedonic returns.

payload.text: Aristotle conceives of ethical theory as a field distinct from the theoretical sciences. Its methodology must match its subject matter--good action--and must respect the fact that in this field many generalizations hold only for the most part. We study ethics in order to improve our lives, and therefore its principal concern is the nature of human well-being. Aristotle follows Socrates and Plato in taking the virtues to be central to a well-lived life. Like Plato, he regards the ethical virtues (justice, courage, temperance and so on) as complex rational, emotional and social skills. But he rejects Plato's idea that to be completely virtuous one must acquire, through a training in the sciences, mathematics, and philosophy, an understanding of what goodness is. What we need, in order to live well, is a proper appreciation of the way in which such goods as friendship, pleasure, virtue, honor and wealth fit together as a whole. In order to apply that general understanding to particular cases, we must acquire, through proper upbringing and habits, the ability to see, on each occasion, which course of action is best supported by reasons.
payload.summary: Aristotle distinguishes ethical theory from theoretical sciences, asserting its methodology should align with its focus on good actions. He acknowledges that many generalizations in ethics apply mostly, not universally. Ethics, according to Aristotle, aims to enhance human life by understanding well-being, a concept he shares with Socrates and Plato, who emphasize virtues as central to a good life. Unlike Plato, Aristotle doesn't require scientific knowledge for complete virtue; instead, he stresses the importance of recognizing how goods like friendship, pleasure, virtue, honor, and wealth interrelate in achieving an overall good life. He posits that practical wisdom, gained through upbringing and habits, enables individuals to discern the best course of action by reason in specific situations.
